  "translated_title": "[Low Birth Rate Talk Talk Episode 7] Career-Interrupted Women's Resumes",
  "translated_text": "Mom's Talk Episode 7 (Career-Interrupted Women's Resumes)

Everyone: Hello.
Chae In-taek: Yes, today I'll be with five people. Please introduce yourselves.
Gold Spoon IV Mom (hereafter IV Mom): Hello, I'm Gold Spoon IV Mom.
Super Stamina Mom (hereafter Stamina Mom): Hello, I'm Super Stamina Mom.
Hyochang-dong Good Wife and Mother (hereafter Good Wife): Hello, I'm Hyochang-dong Good Wife and Mother, back again.
Nakseong-daei Alice (hereafter Alice): Hello, I'm Nakseong-daei Alice.
Pyeongchon Easy Mom (hereafter Easy Mom): Hello, I'm Pyeongchon Easy Mom.
Chae In-taek: Yes. You're all such vibrant people whenever I see you. Today, you vibrant people need to be not just vibrant but truly sharp and go beyond vibrant to really speak boldly about this topic. It's about career-interrupted women. We'll do this under the title 'Career-Interrupted Women's Resumes.' Looking at the situation now, many people have career interruptions due to childcare more than other reasons - because of childbirth and childcare. Because of this, they're seeking new lives or giving up their careers until then, and various things are happening. That's why the government creates employment support systems for career-interrupted women, and the appeals of career-interrupted women often appear in newspapers and broadcasts. What are the careers of today's participants like? Let me hear how secure your careers are.
Easy Mom: I'm Pyeongchon Easy Mom. In my case, I got married at thirty-two, but I think I made the choice of whether to marry or not in my mid-twenties. So my case isn't one of complete career interruption but career reduction, and I voluntarily chose to reduce it. I graduated from university and entered a major corporation where I worked from early morning to evening, until night.
Chae In-taek: Not 9-to-5 but 5-to-11 or something like that?
Easy Mom: Yes, something similar. While living like that, I thought, 'Living this way, can I get married? Can I have children?' When I thought about it, I had to make a choice. After working for about 1-2 years, I thought, 'Ah, this kind of life isn't the life I want,' and 'Since I'm someone who will get married someday, I can't continue like this.' So I voluntarily quit and took the path of studies.
Chae In-taek: Ah, the reason you quit was that in that kind of lifestyle, it would be difficult to get married, have children, and live the life you wanted?
Easy Mom: Yes, impossible.
Chae In-taek: Ah, even impossible?
Easy Mom: I think it's impossible. And at that time, it was the first atmosphere where they were hiring many female college graduates in large numbers. In that atmosphere, I absolutely couldn't slack off at the company or take it easy. Also, because of my school background, the company's expectations of me were very high. So after much consideration, I left that way. While trying to keep my career alive, not to interrupt it, I'm living with continuous efforts, really tearful efforts.
Chae In-taek: You mean a new career? You newly entered graduate school, got married, had a baby, and are building a career while balancing studies and childcare. You're currently a part-time instructor, right?
Easy Mom: Yes.
Good Wife: But last time you said you decided on your major at 15, and this time in your mid-twenties you're looking ahead ten years again... Your foresight is amazing. I'm really, why is this so annoying? Something's annoying about it (haha).
Chae In-taek: You're saying you want to live life in a planned way, but even when you live with plans, such huge obstacles always appear outside your plans.
Easy Mom: I want to live easily.
Good Wife: The destination is similar.
Easy Mom: I plan to live easily, but it turns out to be the same thing.
Chae In-taek: You planned to live easily, but the conclusion is living very hard. Die hard.
Good Wife: You say 'easy' but whether it's really easy is... (I don't know).
Alice: Compared to Easy Mom, I lived really normally, not strangely at all. I graduated from undergraduate school and just like ordinary people, I was lucky enough to enter a major corporation at that time. I entered the corporation and after seeing how the senior colleagues lived, I felt a lot of doubt. They recommended I quit, but when I didn't quit, after seeing them put my desk in front of the tea room, after experiencing that, I quit and thought, 'Ah, studying is my path. As expected,' so I did my master's. When I did my master's, I thought, 'Ah, to study in Korea, you need money,' so I needed that money and to continue studying, I entered a public institution and worked there. Then I passed the doctoral program, but according to graduate school regulations, I had to be a full-time student, so I quit the public institution and started my doctorate.
Good Wife: What a waste.
Easy Mom: That good public institution (you quit).
Chae In-taek: You quit that good public institution job and entered the path of academia?
Alice: Yes. Just like an ordinary person, going to school and studying.
Chae In-taek: Well, it doesn't seem like ordinary people. What kind of values were at work in between?
Alice: It was really ordinary values. I really wanted to maintain eating, living, and my studies as a profession.
Chae In-taek: You wanted to study? You thought it would be good if studying were your profession?
Alice: Because the public institution, unlike general corporations or other companies, would send you to evening graduate school or let you use vacation more easily, although not like civil servants, the atmosphere was such that you could use vacation more easily, so I entered the public institution. So I thought I could do my doctorate that way too, but I learned about the school regulations too late and had to quit.
Chae In-taek: Seoul National University made a regulation a few years ago that for the first two semesters after doctoral admission, you must attend full-time, right?
Alice: Yes. It seems to have been made so you can focus on studies.
Chae In-taek: It has pros and cons, but for our Alice Mom, it could be a damaging occasion.
Alice: Yes. So actually after admission, I took a leave of absence for a year. I also felt the burden of possibly taking away someone else's opportunity (but I had no choice).
Chae In-taek: You took a leave and continued at the public company.
Alice: Yes. I needed to save some money. So I saved money and worked until (before quitting). I really worked continuously without rest. I got pregnant at 35 and gave birth at 36. Until then, I also normally came to graduate school, did projects, and studied. I had really been building my career normally like that, but after getting pregnant, I wasn't particularly overworking myself, I was doing projects and research like ordinary graduate students, but what I hadn't taken care of before was my body, and generally using public transportation. From Seoul to the workplace is a round trip of 2 hours. It's not special for me, it's generally like that. Graduate students are the same, but we usually finish work around 11-12 PM. When there's work to do.
Chae In-taek: Oh, attending graduate school and doing projects, the time you finish and leave is 11 PM?
Alice: That's right. Yes, it's not just me (many people are like that).
Chae In-taek: Not AM? PM 12, 11. Ah yes.
Alice: I think fatigue accumulated. So in the middle of pregnancy, at 20 weeks, about halfway, there was so much bleeding that I had to stop all work and come home. And after giving birth.
Easy Mom: That's when involuntary career interruption began.
Chae In-taek: When you started studying, quitting your previous job was a voluntary choice, but as you were adapting to that life of studying and doing projects, you got pregnant, but at 20 weeks due to bleeding and fatigue, you couldn't bear it anymore, so you involuntarily had to stop graduate school projects and only take care of your health?
Alice: Yes. Probably not just me, but anyone who attended graduate school in Korea... because graduate school isn't like a job where someone looks after you and decides where you go, it's not absolute but something you do yourself, so (everyone would be similar).
Chae In-taek: Everyone outside thinks how rewarding, comfortable, and enjoyable a life of studying must be. But inside the cage, there are tremendous transactions and problems, and especially having and raising a baby while living graduate school life - the problems are as big and difficult as having a job?
Easy Mom: Maybe even bigger (than a job).
Alice: More than a job. Because people too easily say, 'You're studying, so you don't have to (study, work) for a while, right?'
Chae In-taek: Ah, if you have a job, they say 'Work must be hard, so rest and take care of the baby,' but if you're studying, they demand why you can't do it. Ah, this will be an important point.
IV Mom: Yes. And you can't even make money (while doing it).
Chae In-taek: Ah, you can't even make money while... Ah, social perception.
Good Wife: In Korea, people really devalue those who can't take care of themselves (IV Mom: while spending money) and can't earn their keep.
Chae In-taek: Because you earn money, 'How hard you must work to earn money.'
IV Mom: 'You spend money, so why are you like that?'
Chae In-taek: 'You study and spend money, what's so hard about that?'
Good Wife: 'Are you showing off?'
Chae In-taek: Alice Mom, you've experienced both working and the life of studying and doing projects in graduate school. Honestly, there are various cases so horizontal comparison wouldn't work, but based on your experience, what comparison could be made between the two?
Alice: Um, whether you gain physical freedom or mental freedom, spiritual freedom.
Chae In-taek: Spiritual freedom and physical freedom.
Alice: That's what I felt. When working, you have no soul but rather that schedule, especially since my last job was at a public institution. If you move according to that schedule, your mind really doesn't have to focus on that work, which is a characteristic of bureaucracy. It doesn't collapse greatly if one person is missing. It becomes like that, but because you can't do anything according to your will, there's a resulting, how should I say, helplessness? That came to me. Many people don't feel this, but I felt helplessness. So I started studying, but after studying, I feel helpless about the economic situation. Because at the last public institution I worked at, my net income was over 30 million won [approximately $23,000 USD] annually. Net income was (that much) because I had some seniority. But after entering the doctoral program, the maximum pre-tax amount, not net income but pre-tax amount, that you can receive by doing the most projects in the doctoral program is 2.5 million won [approximately $1,900 USD].
Easy Mom: If you received that much from the school, you did a tremendous amount of work.
Chae In-taek: Pre-tax 3000 [million won]. Working until eleven.
Alice: I was a legend. I was the legend who received 2.5 million won [approximately $1,900 USD], but doing that, per month.
Chae In-taek: To become a legend, you have to work until midnight?
Alice: Work until midnight, pull all-nighters three or four times a month, and no weekends.
Chae In-taek: No weekends either?
Alice: Yes, that's right.
Chae In-taek: As a student?
Easy Mom: Oh no, not a student.
Alice: And when reports pile up at year-end, you should think you can't go home for about a week then.
Chae In-taek: What about the baby?
Alice: That was before pregnancy.
Chae In-taek: When you were doing projects before pregnancy?
Alice: Probably people who have children now and work at school (graduate students) really leave their children only at home and only do school work. That's what they have no choice but to do in Korea (that's the reality for graduate students).
Chae In-taek: Just like people who work, they have no choice but to leave children completely at daycare centers or maternal family or, though difficult, paternal grandparents, and come to school to do projects like going to work.
Easy Mom: Otherwise, you can't proceed with studies. For classes, many graduate school classes are offered in the evening.
Chae In-taek: Ah, evening classes are quite helpful for part-time students, but for full-time students, especially student mothers balancing childcare, it can be a very difficult situation.
Easy Mom: And there are very many cases of having lab meetings on Saturdays or workshops on weekends.
Chae In-taek: Laboratory, research lab meetings are rather more common on weekends. Why weekends? Because of professors' schedules?
Easy Mom: During weekdays there are lectures and other classes (so).
Chae In-taek: Because everyone's busy?
Easy Mom: It's also difficult to gather.
Good Wife: My husband did his doctorate in science and engineering, and lab meetings were Saturday mornings. So I asked, 'Why Saturday morning lab meetings?' and he said, 'The advisor professor feels good seeing students research on Saturday mornings. He also did that during his doctorate, so he calls them on Saturdays too to study hard.'
Easy Mom: Saturday morning is common.
Chae In-taek: Ah, this isn't something just one or two of you experienced. You're saying it's not a special case but a universal situation.
Alice: It's a universal situation. And now students also become dual-career couples, but when I put my child on the daycare waiting list, we weren't dual-career yet. So with no place to rely on, either maternal or paternal families, I put my child on the waiting list for national and public daycare centers. Even when I used loopholes and registered as dual-career, it was still so long. My husband and I went directly to see private or home daycare centers. The situation. Then this person, who wouldn't even take care of (the child) himself, said, 'I feel so uncomfortable leaving the child at such a place.' So when there's no place to leave the child and he says he feels so uncomfortable...
Easy Mom: Give up your career.
Alice: If we're not getting divorced, I can't send the child where I want.
Chae In-taek: My goodness, between spouses, crack or friction that could cause... it didn't cause problems, did it?
Alice: No. So that didn't work either. For a babysitter, the house we live in actually has much more debt than assets, but this gets counted as assets.
Good Wife: Are you house poor?
Alice: It's a long story, but because it gets counted as assets, we don't qualify for government support. We'd have to pay for a babysitter mostly out of our own pocket.
Chae In-taek: Ah, if it's counted as assets, it doesn't matter whether you borrowed money, inherited it, or originally had it. It depends on the asset size itself.
Alice: Yes. So in a situation where our home loan payments alone make living expenses tight, as you can see from my appearance, I barely applied lotion before coming out.
Chae In-taek: It's a podcast so we can't see.
Good Wife: That's why you appeared on this?
Alice: Yes, that's why I came out confidently.
Chae In-taek: Ah, you can't appear on video?
Good Wife: There are some people like that here too.
Chae In-taek: You're being too modest.
Alice: Yes. So I had no choice but to come home in September 2013, gave birth in March 2014, and finally my child enters daycare this March, in March 2016. For 2 years and 6 months (as a full-time housewife).
Chae In-taek: So for 2 years and 6 months, you were a full-time housewife at home after childbirth?
Alice: That's right.
Easy Mom: Involuntarily (career interrupted).
Chae In-taek: Until the child could go to daycare, for 2 years and 6 months, there was voluntary job interruption, but also interruption of academic and research career from graduate school.
Alice: That's right. The professor contacted me until last spring, but now hasn't contacted me for a year. But I'm in a position where I have to show the professor again that I'm prepared to this extent, so it's a frustrating situation.
Stamina Mom: You probably can't even think about a second child.
Alice: I think I should have a second child after receiving my doctorate.
Good Wife: Then you'd be an advanced maternal age, elderly primigravida.
Chae In-taek: I have nothing to say.
Easy Mom: Actually, though I briefly mentioned earlier, when I think about the situation then, thinking about preventing my career from being interrupted, tears really blur my vision. Because I was an instructor, if I had a child during the semester, I would lose my teaching, that is, my instructor job. So I had planned pregnancy at the hospital to match the dates.
Chae In-taek: To give birth during vacation?
Easy Mom: Yes. So there's only one chance every 6 months. (Oh my, what to do.) So I got pregnant that way, gave birth just one week after vacation started, and returned to teaching after just 45 days. Really, ah, thinking about that time, tears really blur my vision.
Chae In-taek: This is shocking work that requires studying various fields like biology, physiology, and embryology. Good Wife, how is your career then, and how are you maintaining it now?
Good Wife: I keep hearing 'Good Wife.'
Chae In-taek: The term 'Good Wife' itself isn't about career interruption but career abandonment, isn't it? That's not the case for you, right? You have the will? The will to continue and maintain your career?
Good Wife: I have the will. I have the will, but to be a good wife, of course, I'm worried I might really become a good wife these days. I keep hearing 'good wife' lately. But what should I say... I also worked at a public institution. From after having my first child until before getting pregnant with my second child.
Easy Mom: Ah, why are all these accomplished people like this?
Chae In-taek: You should be going to work now, but you're doing Mom's Talk.
Good Wife: But you can't do all of this together. You have to earn money, live, raise children, and study. My graduate school grades were all B-minuses, and I was taking out student loans to attend graduate school, but when salary comes in from work, it all goes to living expenses and doesn't accumulate. You end up spending as much as you earn. Why are there so many ceremonial occasions? So I quit work and decided 'I'll rather devote myself to studying,' but I couldn't even get into research projects. Because there are young students who can use their time anytime and can be mobilized, young students get into research projects, not someone like me with children. Even when I applied, I wouldn't get selected.
Chae In-taek: The internal logic is 'Young people need opportunities because they're economically struggling, and older people might have worked other jobs and saved money,' is that how they see it?
Good Wife: I think it would be easy to think that way.
Chae In-taek: Is that true?
Alice: Especially for married women, there's someone, the husband, who works and earns money, so 'At any rate, doesn't one person earn?' This also exists.
Chae In-taek: One person in the family earns, so it would be good if you yielded a little. Something like that?
Good Wife: Yes. But actually, our career - if there are several years of gaps on a resume, there's no way to fill them. So I chose a kind of startup. Actually, it's not starting a business enterprise or company, but I started organizing a civil society group. Since my major is social welfare, seeing that the learning rights, human rights, or maternal rights of mother graduate students are in such blind spots of the system, I started making a group and organizing to propose policies about these problems.
Easy Mom: But you worked but didn't receive money or belong anywhere, right?
Good Wife: No monthly salary at all. If I did research projects or something, I donated all my labor costs to Mom in SNU, so I didn't receive salary for the past 4 years. So my husband said just one thing: 'It's good that you go out and work, but please earn some money.'
Chae In-taek: Really a desperate double or triple burden...
Good Wife: So in the power relationship with my husband, the advantage I gained by producing two sons was all lost by not earning money and living off my husband. So while I barely maintained the lifeline, the career on my resume through volunteering.
Chae In-taek: You maintained (career) on your resume through volunteering?
Good Wife: Organizing groups and acting as representative, contributing to women's civil society and student parent human rights, legislative proposals and policy proposals through this, writing research reports, writing policy proposals, requesting legislation. So actually last February, the Parent Student Act passed in the 19th National Assembly. So as Alice Mom mentioned, parent students moved up in daycare waiting priority. They're recognized as dual-career. I did such activities, but life was really at the basic livelihood recipient level.
Chae In-taek: You said 'I kept my career alive through volunteering,' but from a third party's perspective, and especially from your husband's perspective, since cash supply capacity is almost zero, some people might see this as (doing nothing). Your husband might especially strongly think that no career was extended?
Good Wife: It's not just thinking - he says it out loud. Seoul National University master's graduate living off meals.
Chae In-taek: You should prepare boxing gloves or massage equipment at home. Ah, you should prepare that thing you put in your ears?
Good Wife: Earplugs?
Chae In-taek: Earplugs so you can pretend not to know even if you shout at each other.
Easy Mom: Ah, it's earplugs.
Good Wife: Earplugs. You understand perfectly even when I speak unclearly. I gave birth to two sons.
Easy Mom: But please know that much.
Chae In-taek: Never letting it slide (that's Easy Mom).
Good Wife: After two C-sections, my brain became like this.
Chae In-taek: What was the situation before doing this?
Good Wife: Elegant and intelligent.
Chae In-taek: You have very clear excuses, but the passage of time comes to us too, regardless of C-sections. So what story does our Stamina Mom have?
Stamina Mom: I was attending undergraduate school and preparing to try different studies. But in my early twenties, I chose to get married. So I thought, 'I'll get married and then study,' and got married in my early twenties. I'll be really struggling until about 40, but I prepared myself and calculated time and got married. But actually, I had no plans for children. I was really the opposite of Easy Mom - I really couldn't plan. Since I was little, everyone knew I wouldn't get married and I openly said this from a very young age, but I got married in my early twenties and had two children in a row.
IV Mom: People like that originally go early.
Stamina Mom: Yes. So my high school teacher even came. To the wedding.
Easy Mom: I quit work to get married but got married after thirty.
IV Mom: That's how it usually is.
Stamina Mom: So I became a mother in my early twenties. To do new studies, I would have had to enter university again. I was watching for the right time, but that was my thinking - other people were like, 'You got married and had children, haven't you achieved everything?' That was basically the attitude. But that wasn't the case for me, so I tried to study. When I tried to do the studies I wanted, many people said, 'It would be good to study at a lifelong education center.' I'm not trying to disparage that - there are many really good educational institutions. I actually looked into it. But the field I wanted to study required more education. So I decided, 'Let's take CSAT [College Scholastic Ability Test, Korea's national university entrance exam] again,' and started preparing for entrance exams after our second child passed 15 months, starting to turn two.
Easy Mom: How old were you then?
Stamina Mom: I was twenty-seven or twenty-eight. So from then on (I prepared), but what I wanted to study wasn't just studying - I had to do practical skills. So I took CSAT through internet lectures and EBS [Educational Broadcasting System, Korea's state-run educational media] is free. And I did practical skills day and night, took CSAT, took the test again and entered university again. But I heard there are such cases abroad (of late admission). Many, and there are even universities you can go to when you're older. But in Korea (there aren't). I have no support or anything, and everyone around opposed it, so only my husband and I thought about this and did it. We broke all our savings and children's insurance to study. But if I failed, I'd be nothing - it was complete gambling. But I did it! I studied and was really lucky, really thankfully got admitted. But after admission, I rested for 3 years because my child was sick. I had to take care of the child's illness. But it's a problem that depends entirely on me. Other people don't think it's important when you're studying, and don't even think of it as career interruption.
Easy Mom: And at that time, there was no childcare leave for child illness, so it must have been really difficult.
Stamina Mom: And my position is as an undergraduate. It's not a general situation at all. Graduate students or doctoral students usually do that, but an undergraduate getting married and doing this - most cases like this are when young people made mistakes unintentionally. And it interferes with studies themselves. But anyway, those are external difficulties. From my personal standpoint, I'm breaking through that and continuing to finish my studies and create my career while studying.
Good Wife: So this seems like you're a career frontier who tremendously overcame personal and social limitations.
Stamina Mom: That sounds nice (haha).
Good Wife: In Korea, becoming like this - this is almost a legendary figure. But when I went to UC Berkeley and visited the parent student center, there were many undergraduate parent students there. So I was talking with the center director, and there are many people who transfer from community colleges to UC Berkeley, or people who were in the military and come back to state universities after discharge, so there are many people who are parents. It's a good school. But there are second chances, second opportunities like this. It's not that if you fail college entrance once, you live as a life loser, but there are opportunities and systems where you can continuously challenge throughout your life cycle, but in Korea that's very limited, especially coming back to prestigious universities - there are almost no institutional (ways).
Easy Mom: Almost none, we should say.
Stamina Mom: So cases like mine seem very rare at school. Coming in after having two children. So positioning is unclear for me and for the school too - it's somewhat ambiguous.
Good Wife: I was like that too. Coming through independent study degree [a Korean system for earning degrees through self-study and examinations], it was ambiguous.
Chae In-taek: I see. So, self-proclaimed Gold Spoon IV Mom, is your career interruption voluntary, involuntary, due to childbirth and childcare, or a choice for your own upgrade? Let me hear.
IV Mom: I don't know how to classify it either. I also got married quite early. I got married in my senior year of college and was preparing for employment thinking 'I should get a job after marriage,' but I was pregnant. Then with a big belly, I can't do interviews or training. I'm a pregnant woman. Suddenly I went from being a job seeker to a pregnant woman. So I thought, 'Then I should postpone employment for a while' and gave birth.
Chae In-taek: Being pregnant became a kind of status? A personal condition that indicates social position. So you can't even interview, and even if you apply, they ask 'Why did you come in this condition?' Ah, we don't think about that much. We think workplaces are where unmarried, non-pregnant men and women apply, but there are actually many cases like this?
IV Mom: Pregnant women coming to interviews - they can't understand it.
Chae In-taek: You never tried?
IV Mom: So I tried, but pushing myself caused problems with the child's health, and also...
Easy Mom: It's worrying even if you succeed.
IV Mom: Even if successful, suddenly entering and receiving training, then saying I have to go give birth.
Easy Mom: And training involves a lot of physical training and such.
IV Mom: You can't run with a big belly.
Good Wife: You run during training?
Alice, Easy Mom: Team activities like tower building. And overnight mountain climbing for 1 night 2 days, things like that.
IV Mom: Calculating, it didn't work out ambiguously. So I thought I should give birth quickly and get employed quickly. So I gave birth and tried, but (about pregnancy) I had no plans.
Chae In-taek: Ah, to get employed quickly, you gave birth quickly?
IV Mom: 'Hard, hard' - that was my mindset, so during pregnancy I studied English, took English tests with a big belly... thinking as soon as the baby comes out, I'll get employed right away.
Easy Mom: Pregnant job seeker.
IV Mom: A pregnant woman appearing at TEPS [Test of English Proficiency developed by Seoul National University] exam sites.
Chae In-taek: I should have met you then - I can't imagine what that situation would be like. What difficulties were there?
IV Mom: I took all the tests, got all the scores, and gave birth, but oh my, this wasn't the end. I had no plans at all. So I was like 'Oh my, what is this?' and started childcare. I couldn't sleep at night because of nursing. Waking up every 2-3 hours, crying that I'd have no wishes if I could just sleep 5 hours. Living a life that violates human rights for a long time, I gradually lost my mind. And the baby was sick early on, so dealing with that made it even later. I graduated from a good undergraduate school with excellent grades.
Good Wife: Didn't you graduate summa cum laude this time?
Stamina Mom, Easy Mom: Graduate school summa cum laude.
Chae In-taek: Is there summa cum laude in graduate school?
Stamina Mom, Easy Mom: Yes, there is. Then you must go to graduation. You have to go and receive the award.
IV Mom: I didn't even know that and said, 'Ah, I have a part-time job that day, I'm also preparing for employment and have to take care of my child, so I'm busy and can't go,' and they said, 'What are you talking about?' You must come.
Good Wife: What part-time job? Sell one of your gold spoons.
Chae In-taek: Sell one of your gold spoons.
Easy Mom: Still, you have to pay property tax.
Chae In-taek: Taxes must be hard to pay too.
IV Mom: Anyway, people have to figure out how to make a living themselves. As humans. No matter what, it's too embarrassing to ask parents for money, so I tried somehow and studied. Since I originally studied well. I could do what I used to do, but when I tried to get employed after that, my age was already - the child should already be going to elementary school, and I was already at full age, with no career but with very high educational background and excellent grades.
Good Wife: Would they hire you?
Chae In-taek: This is called the problem of late marriage. Especially now, many say late marriage is the biggest cause of low birth rate in overcoming the low birth rate problem. But even with early marriage - early marriage means career interruption, no, career hasn't even started yet.
IV Mom: Can't start.
Good Wife: Using fresh eggs, is that expression weird? Biologically giving birth to a very healthy child...
IV Mom: The child is really smart.
Stamina Mom: Right, healthy too (haha).
Easy Mom: You two who gave birth early.
Chae In-taek: Ah, you seem too focused on biological determinism.
IV Mom: But my career is really unhealthy.
Chae In-taek: The child is healthy, but mom's career is still pre-birth.
IV Mom: Yes. On my resume, after educational background, there's nothing to write.
Everyone: Resume has education, educational background. Summa cum laude (and that's it).
Chae In-taek: I thought grades were one of the factors determining employment, not the decisive factor.
IV Mom: So from my parents' perspective, they're frustrated. 'She studied so well, I spent so much on hagwon education [Note: 사교육 refers specifically to the hagwon/tutoring industry in Korean context], sent her to such a good university, but (look at her now).'
Chae In-taek: Spent money on education but can't even get employed (and is like this). Do they even say 'just' raising children, not 'at least'?
Good Wife: That's not 'could do' but something we always hear.

Everyone: Hello
Chae In-taek: Please introduce yourselves, everyone who came today.

Good Wife: No, it's not like that. The elderly people in our neighborhood like me.
Chae In-taek: We have five people here, how about the other two?

Chae In-taek: Yes, I can picture that image.

Chae In-taek: You have a golden spoon but you're on an IV - pure and pitiful, frail, frequent minor illnesses?

IV Mom: Yes. (Haha)
Chae In-taek: Oh, you answered very vigorously.
IV Mom: Yes, that's right!
Chae In-taek: As expected, when stories about overcoming low birth rates come up, voices get louder in this atmosphere.
Good Wife: It has to be that way.
IV Mom: I powered up briefly before coming today.
Good Wife: You sparkled for a moment.
Chae In-taek: I'll think of it as power going up with strong charging. Today's topic is immigration. It could be an exodus. Countries good for raising children, countries good for working while raising children, countries with evenings, countries where the whole family can comfortably talk about the future - our country falls short in these areas. Alice: Yes, I seriously (thought about it).

Alice: I seriously did. With my husband. Because I had worked on Nepal-related projects for about 4 years before.

Alice: If I talk specifically, my advisor professor might know.

Alice: Related to improving quality of life.
Chae In-taek: It wasn't about Nepal's defense capabilities, right? Ah, while working on quality of life, you seemed to be attracted to that?

Chae In-taek: Ah, not the locals but the lives of Koreans?
